title: Requires the legislature to provide for the maintenance and support of a system of free public libraries
summary: Provides a constitutional guarantee that the legislature shall provide for the maintenance and support of a system of free public libraries, wherein all the residents of this state may be provided with public library services.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S1575

TITLE OF BILL:
CONCURRENT RESOLUTION OF THE SENATE AND ASSEMBLY
proposing an amendment to section 1 of
article 11 of the constitution, in relation to requiring the legislature
to provide for a system of free public libraries

PURPOSE OR GENERAL IDEA OF BILL:
To provide a Constitutional guarantee
of free public library service for all residents of New York State.

SUMMARY OF SPECIFIC PROVISIONS:
Amends § 1 of Article XI of the State
Constitution to add a guarantee of free public library services to
the existing guarantee of free public schools.

JUSTIFICATION:
New York's Constitutional guarantee of free public
schools for all the children of the state has ensured the development
and maintenance of excellent public school systems, establishing the
state's reputation for well-educated citizens who make up a
productive workforce. With rapid changes in technology and the
explosive growth of many fields of learning, the need for life-long
learning has taken on new importance. It is no longer enough to
provide education only to our children. Public libraries -- called by
some, "the people's universities" -- provide the most broadly
available basis for life-long learning and adult education
opportunities. The amendment would recognize the need to guarantee
educational opportunities to all citizens, not just children, by
guaranteeing access to free public libraries. A similar
Constitutional guarantee was added to the Rhode Island State
Constitution in 1986 following approval at a Constitutional
Convention and voter approval by a margin of 68%.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:
2009-2010:  S.5607/A.3895; Opinion referred to Judiciary
2007-2008:  S.3777/A.2834; Opinion referred to Judiciary
2005-2006:  S.2144/A.1554; Opinion referred to Judiciary
2003-2004:  S.738/A.4838;  Opinion referred to Judiciary
2001-2002:  S.3755/A.985;  Opinion referred to Judiciary
1999-2000:  S.1482/A.1641; Opinion referred to Judiciary
1997-1998:  S.1691/A.4655; Opinion referred to Judiciary

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None to the State or local governments. Public
libraries and systems are currently funded by State and local
appropriations, and provide services to all State residents under
statute and regulation. This amendment would provide a Constitutional
guarantee for continuation of free public library services.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
RESOLVED (if the Assembly concur), That the foregoing amendments
be referred to the first regular legislative session convening after
the next succeeding general election of members of the assembly, and,


in conformity with section 1 of article 19 of the constitution, be
published for 3 months previous to the time of such election.
